hints_html:
Try integrating by parts.

Make \(u =e^{2x}\) and \(dv = \sin(2x)dx\).

Try integrating by parts again similar to hint 2.

Try integrating... no wait the integral on the far right looks like the one on the far left!!! So bring it over and simplify. (This is an example of a cyclic integral).
hints_latex: Try integrating by parts again similar to hint 2.

Try integrating... no wait the integral on the far right looks like the
one on the far left!!! So bring it over and simplify. (This is an
example of a cyclic integral).
hints_raw:
Try integrating by parts.
Make <math> u =e^{2x} </math> and <math> dv = \sin(2x)dx </math>.
Try integrating by parts again similar to hint 2.
Try integrating... no wait the integral on the far right looks like the one on the far left!!! So bring it over and simplify. (This is an example of a cyclic integral).
question: 3 (d)
sols_html:
We proceed by integration by parts. Let

\[\begin{aligned} u = e^{2x} \quad & \quad v = -\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} \\ du = 2e^{2x}dx \quad & \quad dv = \sin(2x)dx \end{aligned}\]

and so the integral becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \int e^{2x}\sin(2x)\,dx &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \int e^{2x}\cos(2x) \, dx\end{aligned}\]

We use parts again. Let

\[\begin{aligned} u = e^{2x} \quad & \quad v = \frac{\sin(2x)}{2} \\ du = 2e^{2x}dx \quad & \quad dv = \cos(2x)dx \end{aligned}\]

Then, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int e^{2x}\sin(2x)\,dx &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \int e^{2x}\cos(2x) \, dx\\ &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \left( \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{2} - \int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx \right)\\ &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{2} - \int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx\end{aligned}\]

This last integral on the right is the same as the integral on the left (up to a constant). Hence, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int e^{2x}\sin(2x)\, dx + \int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{2} +C \\ 2\int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{2} +C \\ \int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx &= -\frac{e^{2x}\cos(2x)}{4} + \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{4} +D \end{aligned}\]

where \(D = 2C\). This completes the question.
sols_raw:
We proceed by integration by parts. Let

<math>
\begin{align}
u = e^{2x} \quad & \quad v = -\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} \\
du = 2e^{2x}dx \quad & \quad dv = \sin(2x)dx \\
\end{align}
</math>

and so the integral becomes

<math>
\begin{align}
\int  e^{2x}\sin(2x)\,dx &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2}  + \int e^{2x}\cos(2x) \, dx
\end{align}
</math>

We use parts again. Let

<math>
\begin{align}
u = e^{2x} \quad & \quad v = \frac{\sin(2x)}{2} \\
du = 2e^{2x}dx \quad & \quad dv = \cos(2x)dx \\
\end{align}
</math>

Then, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
\int  e^{2x}\sin(2x)\,dx &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \int e^{2x}\cos(2x) \, dx\\
&= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \left( \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{2} - \int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx \right)\\
&= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{2} - \int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx
\end{align}
</math>

This last integral on the right is the same as the integral on the left (up to a constant). Hence, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
\int  e^{2x}\sin(2x)\, dx +  \int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx  &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{2} +C \\
2\int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx  &= -e^{2x}\frac{\cos(2x)}{2} + \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{2} +C \\
\int e^{2x}\sin(2x) \, dx  &= -\frac{e^{2x}\cos(2x)}{4} + \frac{e^{2x}\sin(2x)}{4} +D \\
\end{align}
</math>

where <math> D = 2C </math>. This completes the question.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required.

Evaluate the following integral.

\(\int e^{2x}\sin 2x\, dx\)
